0.speaker: National Economy
0.text: This debate and the next three—two Presidential, one Vice Presidential—are sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates. Tonight's 90 minutes will be about domestic issues and will follow a format designed by the Commission. There will be six roughly 15-minute segments, with 2-minute answers for the first question, then open discussion for the remainder of each segment.
0.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

1.speaker: National Economy
1.text: Thousands of people offered suggestions on segment subjects or questions via the Internet and other means, but I made the final selections. And for the record, they were not submitted for approval to the Commission or the candidates.
1.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

2.speaker: National Economy
2.text: The segments, as I announced in advance, will be three on the economy and one each on health care, the role of Government, and governing, with an emphasis throughout on differences, specifics, and choices. Both candidates will also have 2-minute closing statements.
2.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

3.speaker: National Economy
3.text: The audience here in the hall has promised to remain silent. No cheers, applause, boos, hisses, among other noisy, distracting things so we may all concentrate on what the candidates have to say.
3.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

4.speaker: National Economy
4.text: There is a noise exception right now, though, as we welcome President Obama and Governor Romney.
4.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

5.speaker: National Economy
5.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

6.speaker: National Economy
6.text: Gentlemen, welcome to you both. Let's start the economy, segment one, and let's begin with jobs. What are the major differences between the two of you about how you would go about creating new jobs? You have 2 minutes—each of you have 2 minutes to start. A coin toss has determined, Mr. President, you go first.
6.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

7.speaker: The President.
7.text: Well, thank you very much, Jim, for this opportunity. I want to thank Governor Romney, and the University of Denver for your hospitality.
7.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

8.speaker: Laughter
8.text: There are a lot of points I want to make tonight, but the most important one is that 20 years ago, I became the luckiest man on Earth because Michelle Obama agreed to marry me. [
8.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

9.speaker: Laughter
9.text: Four years ago, we went through the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. Millions of jobs were lost. The auto industry was on the brink of collapse. The financial system had frozen up. And because of the resilience and the determination of the American people, we've begun to fight our way back. Over the last 30 months, we've seen 5 million jobs in the private sector created. The auto industry has come roaring back, and housing has begun to rise.
9.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

10.speaker: Laughter
10.text: But we all know that we've still got a lot of work to do. And so the question here tonight is not where we've been, but where we're going.
10.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

11.speaker: Laughter
11.text: Governor Romney has a perspective that says if we cut taxes skewed towards the wealthy and roll back regulations that we'll be better off. I've got a different view. I think we've got to invest in education and training. I think it's important for us to develop new sources of energy here in America; that we change our Tax Code to make sure that we're helping small businesses and companies that are investing here in the United States; that we take some of the money that we're saving as we wind down two wars to rebuild America; and that we reduce our deficit in a balanced way that allows us to make these critical investments.
11.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

12.speaker: Laughter
12.text: Now, it ultimately is going to be up to the voters—to you—which path we should take. Are we going to double down on the top-down economic policies that helped to get us into this mess? Or do we embrace a new economic patriotism that says America does best when the middle class does best? And I'm looking forward to having that debate.
12.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

13.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
13.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

14.speaker: Republican Presidential Nominee W. Mitt Romney.
14.text: Thank you, Jim. It's an honor to be here with you, and I appreciate the chance to be with the President. I'm pleased to be at the University of Denver, I appreciate their welcome, and also the Presidential Commission on these debates.
14.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

15.speaker: laughter
15.text: And congratulations to you, Mr. President, on your anniversary. I'm sure this was the most romantic place you could imagine, here with me. So I—[
15.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

16.speaker: laughter
16.text: This is obviously a very tender topic. I've had the occasion over the last couple of years of meeting people across the country. I was in Dayton, Ohio, and a woman grabbed my arm and she said, I've been out of work since May, can you help me? Ann yesterday was at a rally in Denver, and a woman came up to her with a baby in her arms and said, Ann, my husband has had four jobs in 3 years, part-time jobs. He's lost his most recent job, and we've now just lost our home. Can you help us?
16.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

17.speaker: laughter
17.text: And the answer is, yes, we can help, but it's going to take a different path, not the one we've been on, not the one the President describes as a top-down, cut taxes for the rich; that's not what I'm going to do. My plan has five basic parts: One, get us energy independent, North American energy independent. That creates about 4 million jobs. Number two, open up more trade, particularly in Latin America; crack down on China if and when they cheat. Number three, make sure our people have the skills they need to succeed and the best schools in the world; we are far away from that now. Number four, get us to a balanced budget. Number five, champion small business.
17.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

18.speaker: laughter
18.text: It's small business that creates the jobs in America. And over the last 4 years, small-businesspeople have decided that America may not be the place to open a new business, because new business startups are down to a 30-year low. I know what it takes to get small business growing again, to hire people.
18.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

19.speaker: laughter
19.text: Now, I'm concerned that the path that we're on has just been unsuccessful. The President has a view very similar to the view he had when he ran 4 years ago: that a bigger Government spending more, taxing more, regulating more—if you will, trickle-down Government—would work. That's not the right answer for America. I'll restore the vitality that gets America working again. Thank you.
19.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

20.speaker: Education/Tax Code Reform/Energy
20.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

21.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
21.text: Mr. President, please respond directly to what the Governor just said about trickle down—his trickle-down approach, as he said yours is.
21.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

22.speaker: The President.
22.text: Well, let me talk specifically about what I think we need to do. First, we've got to improve our education system. And we've made enormous progress drawing on ideas both from Democrats and Republicans that are already starting to show gains in some of the toughest-to-deal-with schools.
22.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

23.speaker: The President.
23.text: We've got a program called Race to the Top that has prompted reforms in 46 States around the country, raising standards, improving how we train teachers. So now I want to hire another hundred thousand new math and science teachers and create 2 million more slots in our community colleges so that people can get trained for the jobs that are out there right now. And I want to make sure that we keep tuition low for our young people.
23.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

24.speaker: The President.
24.text: When it comes to our Tax Code, Governor Romney and I both agree that our corporate tax rate is too high. So I want to lower it, particularly for manufacturing—taking it down to 25 percent—but I also want to close those loopholes that are giving incentives for companies that are shipping jobs overseas. I want to provide tax breaks for companies that are investing here in the United States.
24.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

25.speaker: The President.
25.text: On energy, Governor Romney and I, we both agree that we've got to boost American energy production. And oil and natural gas production are higher than they've been in years. But I also believe that we've got to look at the energy sources of the future, like wind and solar and biofuels, and make those investments.
25.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

26.speaker: The President.
26.text: So all of this is possible. Now, in order for us to do it, we do have to close our deficit. And one of the things I'm sure we'll be discussing tonight is how do we deal with our Tax Code and how do we make sure that we are reducing spending in a responsible way, but also how do we have enough revenue to make those investments.
26.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

27.speaker: The President.
27.text: And this is where there's a difference, because Governor Romney's central economic plan calls for a $5 trillion tax cut on top of the extension of the Bush tax cuts—that's another trillion dollars—and $2 trillion in additional military spending that the military hasn't asked for. That's $8 trillion. How we pay for that, reduce the deficit, and make the investments that we need to make without dumping those costs onto middle class Americans, I think, is one of the central questions of this campaign.
27.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

28.speaker: Economic Concerns/Job Training/Tax Code Reform/Energy
28.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

29.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
29.text: Both of you have spoken about a lot of different things. And we're going to try to get through them in as specific a way as we possibly can. But first, Governor Romney, do you have a question that you'd like to ask the President directly about something he just said?
29.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

30.speaker: Gov. Romney.
30.text: Well, sure, I'd like to clear up the record and go through piece by piece. First of all, I don't have a $5 trillion tax cut. I don't have a tax cut of the scale that you're talking about. My view is that we ought to provide tax relief to people in the middle class. But I'm not going to reduce the share of taxes paid by high-income people. High-income people are doing just fine in this economy. They'll do fine whether you're President or I am.
30.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

31.speaker: Gov. Romney.
31.text: The people who are having a hard time right now are middle-income Americans. Under the President's policies, middle-income Americans have been buried. They're just being crushed. Middle-income Americans have seen their income come down by $4,300. This is a tax in and of itself. I'll call it the economy tax. It's been crushing.
31.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

32.speaker: Gov. Romney.
32.text: At the same time, gasoline prices have doubled under the President, electric rates are up, food prices are up, health care costs have gone up by $2,500 a family. Middle-income families are being crushed. And so the question is, how to get them going again? And I've described it. It's energy and trade, the right kind of training programs, balancing our budget, and helping small business. Those are the cornerstones of my plan.
32.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

33.speaker: Gov. Romney.
33.text: But the President mentioned a couple of other ideas I'll just note. First, education. I agree education is key, particularly the future of our economy. But our training programs right now, we've got 47 of them housed in the Federal Government, reporting to 8 different agencies. Overhead is overwhelming. We've got to get those dollars back to the States and go to the workers so they can create their own pathways to get in the training they need for jobs that will really help them.
33.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

34.speaker: Gov. Romney.
34.text: The second area, taxation. We agree we ought to bring the tax rates down, and I do: both for corporations and for individuals. But in order for us not to lose revenue and have the Government run out of money, I also lower deductions and credits and exemptions so that we keep taking in the same money when you also account for growth.
34.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

35.speaker: Gov. Romney.
35.text: The third area, energy. Energy is critical, and the President pointed out correctly that production of oil and gas in the U.S. is up, but not due to his policies. In spite of his policies. Mr. President, all of the increase in natural gas and oil has happened on private land, not on Government land. On Government land, your administration has cut the number of permits and licenses in half.
35.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

36.speaker: Gov. Romney.
36.text: If I'm President, I'll double them and also get the oil from offshore in Alaska, and I'll bring that pipeline in from Canada. And by the way, I like coal. I'm going to make sure we can continue to burn clean coal. People in the coal industry feel like it's getting crushed by your policies. I want to get America and North America energy independent so we can create those jobs.
36.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

37.speaker: Gov. Romney.
37.text: And finally, with regards to that tax cut, look, I'm not looking to cut massive taxes and to reduce the revenues going to the Government. My number-one principle is there will be no tax cut that adds to the deficit. I want to underline that: no tax cut that adds to the deficit. But I do want to reduce the burden paid—being paid by middle-income Americans. And to do that, that also means I cannot reduce the burden paid by high-income Americans. So any language to the contrary is simply not accurate.
37.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

38.speaker: Tax Relief/Tax Code Reform
38.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

39.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
39.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

40.speaker: The President.
40.text: Well, I think—let's talk about taxes because I think it's instructive. Now, 4 years ago when I stood on this stage, I said that I would cut taxes for middle class families, and that's exactly what I did. We cut taxes for middle class families by about $3,600.
40.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

41.speaker: The President.
41.text: And the reason is because I believe that we do best when the middle class is doing well. And by giving them those tax cuts, they had a little more money in their pocket, and so maybe they can buy a new car. They are certainly in a better position to weather the extraordinary recession that we went through. They can buy a computer for their kid who is going off to college, which means they're spending more money, businesses have more customers, businesses make more profits and then hire more workers.
41.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

42.speaker: The President.
42.text: Now, Governor Romney's proposal that he has been promoting for 18 months calls for a $5 trillion tax cut on top of $2 trillion of additional spending for our military. And he is saying that he is going to pay for it by closing loopholes and deductions. The problem is that he's been asked over a hundred times how you would close those deductions and loopholes, and he hasn't been able to identify them.
42.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

43.speaker: The President.
43.text: But I'm going to make an important point here, Jim. When you add up all the loopholes and deductions that upper income individuals can—are currently taking advantage of, you take those all away, you don't come close to paying for $5 trillion in tax cuts and $2 trillion in additional military spending.
43.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

44.speaker: The President.
44.text: And that's why independent studies looking at this said the only way to meet Governor Romney's pledge of not reducing the deficit—or not adding to the deficit is by burdening middle class families; the average middle class family with children would pay about $2,000 more.
44.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

45.speaker: The President.
45.text: Now, that's not my analysis. That's the analysis of economists who have looked at this. And that kind of top-down economics, where folks at the top are doing well, so the average person making 3 million bucks is getting a $250,000 tax break, while middle class families are burdened further, that's not what I believe is a recipe for economic growth.
45.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

46.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
46.text: All right, what is the difference? Let's just stay on taxes for a——
46.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

47.speaker: Gov. Romney.
47.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

48.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
48.text: Let's just stay on taxes for a moment here.
48.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

49.speaker: Gov. Romney.
49.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

50.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
50.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

51.speaker: Gov. Romney.
51.text: ——virtually everything he just said about my tax plan is inaccurate.
51.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

52.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
52.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

53.speaker: Gov. Romney.
53.text: So if the tax plan he described were a tax plan I was asked to support, I'd say, absolutely not. I'm not looking for a $5 trillion tax cut. What I've said is, I won't put in place a tax cut that adds to the deficit. That's part one. So there's no economist can say Mitt Romney's tax plan adds $5 trillion if I say I will not add to the deficit with my tax plan.
53.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

54.speaker: Laughter
54.text: Number two, I will not reduce the share paid by high-income individuals. I know that you and your running mate keep saying that, and I know it's a popular thing to say with a lot of people, but it's just not the case. Look, I've got five boys. I'm used to people saying something that's not always true, but just keep on repeating it and ultimately hoping I'll believe it. [
54.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

55.speaker: Laughter
55.text: And number three, I will not, under any circumstances, raise taxes on middle-income families. I will lower taxes on middle-income families. Now, you cite a study. There are six other studies that looked at the study you described and say it's completely wrong. I saw a study that came out today that said you're going to raise taxes by 3 to $4,000 on middle-income families. Throw all these studies out there.
55.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

56.speaker: Laughter
56.text: But let's get to the bottom line. That is, I want to bring down rates. I want to bring the rates down, at the same time, lower deductions and exemptions and credits and so forth, so we keep getting the revenue we need. And you think, well, then why lower the rates? And the reason is, because small business pays that individual rate. Fifty-four percent of America's workers work in businesses that are taxed not at the corporate tax rate, but at the individual tax rate. And if we lower that rate, they will be able to hire more people.
56.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

57.speaker: Laughter
57.text: For me, this is about jobs.
57.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

58.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
58.text: All right, that's where we started.
58.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

59.speaker: Mr. Romney
59.text: . This is about getting jobs for the American people.
59.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

60.speaker: Tax Code Reform/Small Business Promotion
60.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

61.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
61.text: Yes. Do you challenge what the Governor just said about his own plan?
61.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

62.speaker: The President.
62.text: Well, for 18 months, he's been running on this tax plan. And now, 5 weeks before the election, he's saying that his big, bold idea is "never mind." And the fact is that if you are lowering the rates the way you described, Governor, then it is not possible to come up with enough deductions and loopholes that only affect high-income individuals to avoid either raising the deficit or burdening the middle class. It's math. It's arithmetic.
62.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

63.speaker: The President.
63.text: Now, Governor Romney and I do share a deep interest in encouraging small-business growth. So at the same time that my tax plan has already lowered taxes for 98 percent of families, I also lowered taxes for small business 18 times. And what I want to do is continue the tax rates—the tax cuts that we put into place for small businesses and families.
63.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

64.speaker: The President.
64.text: But I have said that for incomes over $250,000 a year that we should go back to the rates that we had when Bill Clinton was President, when we created 23 million new jobs, went from deficit to surplus, and created a whole lot of millionaires to boot. And the reason this is important is because, by doing that, we can not only reduce the deficit, we can not only encourage job growth through small businesses, but we're also able to make the investments that are necessary in education or in energy.
64.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

65.speaker: The President.
65.text: And we do have a difference, though, when it comes to definitions of small business. Under my plan, 97 percent of small businesses would not see their income taxes go up. Governor Romney says, well, those top 3 percent, they're the job creators, they'd be burdened. But under Governor Romney's definition, there are a whole bunch of millionaires and billionaires who are small businesses. Donald Trump is a small business. And I know Donald Trump doesn't like to think of himself as small anything, but that's how you define small businesses if you're getting business income.
65.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

66.speaker: The President.
66.text: And that kind of approach, I believe, will not grow our economy, because the only way to pay for it without either burdening the middle class or blowing up our deficit is to make drastic cuts in things like education, making sure that we are continuing to invest in basic science and research—all the things that are helping America grow. And I think that would be a mistake.
66.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

67.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
67.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

68.speaker: Gov. Romney.
68.text: Jim, let me just come back on that point, which is these——
68.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

69.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
69.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

70.speaker: Gov. Romney.
70.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

71.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
71.text: Excuse me, just so everybody understands, we're way over our first 15 minutes.
71.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

72.speaker: Gov. Romney.
72.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

73.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
73.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

74.speaker: The President.
74.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

75.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
75.text: Great, no problem. As long as you all don't have a problem, I don't have a problem.
75.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

76.speaker: Gov. Romney.
76.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

77.speaker: Small Business Promotion/Tax Code Reform/Job Creation
77.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

78.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
78.text: Because we're still on the economy. We're going to come back to taxes, and we're going to move on to the deficit and a lot of other things too. But go ahead, sir.
78.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

79.speaker: Gov. Romney.
79.text: You bet. President, you're—Mr. President, you're absolutely right, which is that with regards to 97 percent of the businesses are not taxed at the 35 percent tax rate, they're taxed at a lower rate. But those businesses that are in the last 3 percent of businesses happen to employ half—half—of all the people who work in small business. Those are the businesses that employ one-quarter of all the workers in America. And your plan is to take their tax rate from 35 percent to 40 percent.
79.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

80.speaker: Gov. Romney.
80.text: Now, I talked to a guy who has a very small business. He's in the electronics business in St. Louis. He has four employees. He said he and his son calculated how much they pay in taxes: Federal income tax, Federal payroll tax, State income tax, State sales tax, State property tax, gasoline tax. It added up to well over 50 percent of what they earned. And your plan is to take the tax rate on successful small businesses from 35 percent to 40 percent. The National Federation of Independent Businesses has said that will cost 700,000 jobs.
80.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

81.speaker: Gov. Romney.
81.text: I don't want to cost jobs. My priority is jobs. And so what I do is I bring down the tax rates, lower deductions and exemptions, the same idea behind Bowles-Simpson, by the way—get the rates down, lower deductions and exemptions to create more jobs—because there's nothing better for getting us to a balanced budget than having more people working, earning more money, paying more taxes. That's by far the most effective and efficient way to get this budget balanced.
81.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

82.speaker: The President.
82.text: Jim, I—you may want to move on to another topic, but I would just say this to the American people: If you believe that we can cut taxes by $5 trillion and add $2 trillion in additional spending that the military is not asking for—$7 trillion—just to give you a sense, over 10 years, that's more than our entire defense budget—and you think that by closing loopholes and deductions for the well-to-do, somehow you will not end up picking up the tab, then Governor Romney's plan may work for you.
82.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

83.speaker: The President.
83.text: But I think math, common sense, and our history shows us that's not a recipe for job growth. Look, we've tried this; we've tried both approaches. The approach that Governor Romney is talking about is the same sales pitch that was made in 2001 and 2003. And we ended up with the slowest job growth in 50 years. We ended up moving from surplus to deficits, and it all culminated in the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.
83.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

84.speaker: The President.
84.text: Bill Clinton tried the approach that I'm talking about. We created 23 million new jobs. We went from deficit to surplus. And businesses did very well. So in some ways we've got some data on which approach is more likely to create jobs and opportunity for Americans. And I believe that the economy works best when middle class families are getting tax breaks so that they've got some money in their pockets and those of us who have done extraordinarily well because of this magnificent country that we live in, that we can afford to do a little bit more to make sure we're not blowing up the deficit.
84.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

85.speaker: Gov. Romney.
85.text: Jim, the President began this segment, so I think I get the last word. So I'm going to take it.
85.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

86.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
86.text: Well, you're going to get the first part in the next segment.
86.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

87.speaker: Gov. Romney.
87.text: Well, but he gets the first word of that segment. I get the last word of that segment. Well, I hope. Let me just make this comment.
87.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

88.speaker: The President
88.text: . He can have them, he can have them. Go ahead. [
88.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

89.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
89.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

90.speaker: The President
90.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

91.speaker: Gov. Romney.
91.text: Let me repeat what I said.
91.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

92.speaker: The President
92.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

93.speaker: Gov. Romney.
93.text: I'm not in favor of a $5 trillion tax cut. That's not my plan. My plan is not to put in place any tax cut that will add to the deficit. That's point one. So you may keep referring to it as a $5 trillion tax cut, but that's not my plan.
93.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

94.speaker: The President
94.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

95.speaker: Gov. Romney.
95.text: Number two, let's look at history. My plan is not like anything that's been tried before. My plan is to bring down rates, but also bring down deductions and exemptions and credits at the same time so the revenue stays in, but that we bring down rates to get more people working. My priority is putting people back to work in America. They're suffering in this country.
95.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

96.speaker: Gov. Romney.
96.text: And we talk about evidence. Look at the evidence of the last 4 years. It's absolutely extraordinary. We've got 23 million people out of work or stopped looking for work in this country.
96.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

97.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
97.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

98.speaker: Gov. Romney.
98.text: It's just—we've got—when the President took office, 32 million people on food stamps, 47 million on food stamps today; economic growth this year slower than last year and last year slower than the year before. Going forward with the status quo is not going to cut it for the American people who are struggling today.
98.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

99.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
99.text: All right, let's talk specifics. We're still on the economy. This is theoretically now a second segment, still on the economy, and specifically on what to do about the Federal deficit, the Federal debt. And the question—you each have 2 minutes on this. And Governor Romney, you go first because the President went first on segment one.
99.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

100.speaker: Gov. Romney.
100.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

101.speaker: Deficit and National Debt/Spending Cuts
101.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

102.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
102.text: And the question is this: What are the differences between the two of you as to how you would go about tackling the deficit problem in this country?
102.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

103.speaker: Gov. Romney.
103.text: Well, good. I'm glad you raised that, and it's a critical issue. I think it's not just an economic issue. I think it's a moral issue. I think it's frankly not moral for my generation to keep spending massively more than we take in, knowing those burdens are going to passed on to the next generation, and they're going to be paying the interest and the principal all their lives. And the amount of debt we're adding, at a trillion a year, is simply not moral.
103.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

104.speaker: Gov. Romney.
104.text: So how do we deal with it? Well, mathematically, there are three ways that you can cut a deficit. One, of course, is to raise taxes. Number two is to cut spending. And number three is to grow the economy, because if more people work in a growing economy, they're paying taxes and you can get the job done that way.
104.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

105.speaker: Gov. Romney.
105.text: The President would prefer raising taxes. I understand. The problem with raising taxes is that it slows down the rate of growth and you can never quite get the job done. I want to lower spending and encourage economic growth at the same time.
105.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

106.speaker: Gov. Romney.
106.text: What things would I cut from spending? Well, first of all, I will eliminate all programs by this test if they don't pass it: Is the program so critical it's worth borrowing money from China to pay for it? And if not, I'll get rid of it. Obamacare is on my list. I apologize, Mr. President. I use that term with all respect.
106.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

107.speaker: The President.
107.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

108.speaker: Gov. Romney.
108.text: Good. Okay, good. So I'll get rid of that. I'm sorry, Jim, I'm going to stop the subsidy to PBS. I'm going to stop other things. I like PBS. I love Big Bird. I actually like you too. But I'm not going to keep on spending money on things to borrow money from China to pay for it. That's number one.
108.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

109.speaker: Gov. Romney.
109.text: Number two, I'll take programs that are currently good programs, but, I think, could be run more efficiently at the State level and send them to the State.
109.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

110.speaker: Gov. Romney.
110.text: Number three, I'll make Government more efficient. We're going to cut back the number of employees, combine some agencies and departments. My cutbacks will be done through attrition, by the way.
110.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

111.speaker: Gov. Romney.
111.text: This is the approach we have to take to get America to a balanced budget. The President said he'd cut the deficit in half. Unfortunately, he doubled it. Trillion-dollar deficits for the last 4 years. The President has put in place as much public debt—almost as much debt held by the public as all prior Presidents combined.
111.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

112.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
112.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

113.speaker: The President.
113.text: When I walked into the Oval Office I had more than a trillion-dollar deficit greeting me, and we know where it came from: two wars that were paid for on a credit card, two tax cuts that were not paid for, and a whole bunch of programs that were not paid for, and then a massive economic crisis.
113.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

114.speaker: The President.
114.text: And despite that, what we've said is, yes, we had to take some initial emergency measures to make sure we didn't slip into a great depression, but what we've also said is, let's make sure that we are cutting out those things that are not helping us grow. So 77 Government programs, everything from aircrafts that the Air Force had ordered, but weren't working very well, 18 Government programs for education that were well intentioned, but weren't helping kids learn.
114.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

115.speaker: The President.
115.text: We went after medical fraud in Medicare and Medicaid very aggressively, more aggressively than ever before, and have saved tens of billions of dollars: $50 billion of waste taken out of the system. And I worked with Democrats and Republicans to cut a trillion dollars out of our discretionary domestic budget. That's the largest cut in the discretionary domestic budget since Dwight Eisenhower.
115.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

116.speaker: The President.
116.text: Now, we all know that we've got to do more, and so I put forward a specific $4 trillion deficit reduction plan. It's on a web site; you can look at all the numbers: what cuts we make and what revenue we raise. And the way we do it is $2.50 for every cut we ask for a dollar of additional revenue, paid for, as I indicated earlier, by asking those of us who have done very well in this country to contribute a little bit more to reduce the deficit.
116.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

117.speaker: The President.
117.text: Governor Romney earlier mentioned the Bowles-Simpson Commission. Well, that's how the Commission—bipartisan Commission that talked about how we should move forward, suggested we have to do it—in a balanced way with some revenue and some spending cuts. And this is a major difference that Governor Romney and I have. Let me just finish this point because you're looking for contrast.
117.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

118.speaker: The President.
118.text: When Governor Romney stood on a stage with other Republican candidates for the nomination, and he was asked, would you take $10 of spending cuts for just $1 of revenue? And he said no. Now, if you take such an unbalanced approach, then that means you are going to be gutting our investments in schools and education. It means that——
118.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

119.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
119.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

120.speaker: The President
120.text: . Governor Romney talked about Medicaid and how we could send it back to the States, but effectively, this means a 30-percent cut in the primary program we help for seniors who are in nursing homes, for kids who are with disabilities. And that is not a right strategy for us to move forward.
120.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

121.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
121.text: Mr. President, sorry. Way over the 2 minutes.
121.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

122.speaker: The President.
122.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

123.speaker: National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform/Deficit and National Debt
123.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

124.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
124.text: Governor, what about Simpson-Bowles? Will you support Simpson-Bowles?
124.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

125.speaker: Gov. Romney.
125.text: Simpson-Bowles, the President should have grabbed that.
125.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

126.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
126.text: No, I mean do you support -Simpson-Bowles?
126.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

127.speaker: Gov. Romney.
127.text: I have my own plan. It's not the same as Simpson-Bowles. But in my view, the President should have grabbed it. If you wanted to make some adjustments to it, take it, go to Congress, fight for it.
127.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

128.speaker: The President.
128.text: That's what we've done, made some adjustments to it, and we're putting it forward before Congress right now, a $4 trillion plan——
128.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

129.speaker: Gov. Romney.
129.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

130.speaker: The President.
130.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

131.speaker: Gov. Romney.
131.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

132.speaker: The President
132.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

133.speaker: Gov. Romney.
133.text: You said you'd cut the deficit in half. It's now 4 years later; we still have trillion-dollar deficits. The CBO says we'll have a trillion-dollar deficit each of the next 4 years. If you're reelected, we'll get to a trillion-dollar debt. But you have said before you'd cut the deficit in half. And this four—I love this idea of $4 trillion in cuts: You found $4 trillion of ways to reduce or to get closer to a balanced budget, except we still show trillion-dollar deficits every year. That doesn't get the job done.
133.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

134.speaker: Gov. Romney.
134.text: Let me come back and say, why is that I don't want to raise taxes? Why don't I want to raise taxes on people? And actually you said it. Back in 2010, you said, look, I'm going to extend the tax policies that we have. Now, I'm not going to raise taxes on anyone because when the economy is growing slow like this, when we're in recession, you shouldn't raise taxes on anyone. Well, the economy is still growing slow. As a matter of fact, it's growing much more slowly now than when you made that statement. And so if you believe the same thing, you just don't want to raise taxes on people.
134.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

135.speaker: Gov. Romney.
135.text: And the reality is, it's not just wealthy people—you mentioned Donald Trump—it's not just Donald Trump you're taxing. It's all those businesses that employ one-quarter of the workers in America, these small businesses that are taxed as individuals. You raise taxes, and you kill jobs. That's why the National Federation of Independent Businesses said your plan will kill 700,000 jobs. I don't want to kill jobs in this environment.
135.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

136.speaker: Gov. Romney.
136.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

137.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
137.text: Let's let him answer the taxes thing for a moment.
137.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

138.speaker: Gov. Romney.
138.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

139.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
139.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

140.speaker: The President.
140.text: Well, we've had this discussion before——
140.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

141.speaker: Balancing Tax Code Reform and Spending Cuts/Oil Industry Subsidies/Corporate Tax Deductions
141.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

142.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
142.text: No, about the idea that in order to reduce the deficit, there has to be revenue in addition to cuts.
142.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

143.speaker: The President.
143.text: Right. There has to be revenue in addition to cuts. Now, Governor Romney has ruled out revenue. He's ruled out revenue.
143.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

144.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
144.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

145.speaker: Gov. Romney.
145.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

146.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
146.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

147.speaker: Gov. Romney.
147.text: Look, the revenue I get is by more people working, getting higher pay, paying more taxes. That's how we get growth and how we balance the budget. But the idea of taxing people more, putting more people out of work, you'll never get there. You never balance the budget by raising taxes. Spain—Spain spends 42 percent of their total economy on government.
147.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

148.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
148.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

149.speaker: Gov. Romney.
149.text: We're now spending 42 percent of our economy on Government. I don't want to go down the path to Spain. I want to go down the path of growth that puts Americans to work with more money coming in because they're working.
149.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

150.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
150.text: Yes, but, Mr. President, you're saying in order to get the job done, it's got to be balanced.
150.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

151.speaker: The President.
151.text: If we're serious, we've got to take a balanced, responsible approach. And by the way, this is not just when it comes to individual taxes. Let's talk about corporate taxes. Now, I've identified areas where we can right away make a change that I believe would actually help the economy. The oil industry gets $4 billion a year in corporate welfare. Basically, they get deductions that those small businesses that Governor Romney refers to, they don't get. Now, does anybody think that ExxonMobil needs some extra money when they're making money every time you go to the pump?
151.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

152.speaker: The President.
152.text: Why wouldn't we want to eliminate that? Why wouldn't we eliminate tax breaks for corporate jets? My attitude is, if you got a corporate jet, you can probably afford to pay full freight, not get a special break for it.
152.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

153.speaker: The President.
153.text: When it comes to corporate taxes, Governor Romney has said he wants to, in a revenue-neutral way, close loopholes, deductions—he hasn't identified which ones they are—but that thereby bring down the corporate rate. Well, I want to do the same thing, but I've actually identified how we can do that. And part of the way to do it is to not give tax breaks to companies that are shipping jobs overseas. Right now you can actually take a deduction for moving a plant overseas. I think most Americans would say that doesn't make sense. And all that raises revenue.
153.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

154.speaker: The President.
154.text: And so if we take a balanced approach, what that then allows us to do is also to help young people, the way we already have during my administration, make sure that they can afford to go to college. It means that the teacher that I met in Las Vegas, a wonderful young lady, who describes to me, she's got 42 kids in her class. The first 2 weeks, she's got some of them sitting on the floor until finally they get reassigned. They're using textbooks that are 10 years old. That is not a recipe for growth. That's not how America was built.
154.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

155.speaker: The President.
155.text: And so budgets reflect choices. Ultimately, we're going to have to make some decisions. And if we're asking for no revenue, then that means that we've got to get rid of a whole bunch of stuff. And the magnitude of the tax cuts that you're talking about, Governor, would end up resulting in severe hardship for people, but more importantly, would not help us grow.
155.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

156.speaker: The President.
156.text: As I indicated before, when you talk about shifting Medicaid to States, we're talking about potentially a 30-percent cut in Medicaid over time. Now, that may not seem like a big deal when it just is paper—numbers on a sheet of paper. But if we're talking about a family who's got an autistic kid and is depending on that Medicaid, that's a big problem. And Governors are creative, there's no doubt about it. But they're not creative enough to make up for 30 percent of revenue on something like Medicaid. What ends up happening is some people end up not getting help.
156.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

157.speaker: Gov. Romney.
157.text: Jim, let's—we've gone on a lot of topics there.
157.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

158.speaker: Gov. Romney.
158.text: And so it's going to take a minute to go from Medicaid to schools——
158.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

159.speaker: The President
159.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

160.speaker: Energy Sector Subsidies/Corporate Tax Rates/Medicaid
160.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

161.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
161.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

162.speaker: Gov. Romney.
162.text: ——to oil to tax breaks and companies going overseas. So let's go through them one by one.
162.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

163.speaker: Gov. Romney.
163.text: First of all, the Department of Energy has said the tax break for oil companies is $2.8 billion a year. And it's actually an accounting treatment, as you know, that's been in place for a hundred years. Now——
163.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

164.speaker: The President.
164.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

165.speaker: Gov. Romney.
165.text: And in 1 year, you provided $90 billion in breaks to the green energy world. Now, I like green energy as well, but that's about 50 years' worth of what oil and gas receives. And you say Exxon and Mobil; actually, those $2.8 billion goes largely to small companies, to drilling operators and so forth.
165.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

166.speaker: Gov. Romney.
166.text: But you know if we get that tax rate from 35 percent down to 25 percent, why, that $2.8 billion is on the table. Of course, it's on the table. That's probably not going to survive if you get that rate down to 25 percent. But don't forget, you put $90 billion—like 50 years' worth of breaks—into solar and wind: to Solyndra and Fisker and Tesla and Ener1. I mean, I had a friend who said you don't just pick the winners and losers, you pick the losers. All right? So this is not the kind of policy you want to have if you want to get America energy secure.
166.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

167.speaker: Gov. Romney.
167.text: The second topic, which is you said you get a deduction for taking a plant overseas, look, I've been in business for 25 years. I have no idea what you're talking about. I maybe need to get a new accountant.
167.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

168.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
168.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

169.speaker: Gov. Romney
169.text: . But the idea that you get a break for shipping jobs overseas is simply not the case. What we do have right now is a setting where I'd like to bring money from overseas back to this country.
169.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

170.speaker: Gov. Romney
170.text: And finally, Medicaid to States, I'm not quite sure where that came in except this, which is, I would like to take the Medicaid dollars that go to States and say to a State, you're going to get what you got last year plus inflation, plus 1 percent. And then, you're going to manage your care for your poor in the way you think best.
170.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

171.speaker: Gov. Romney
171.text: And I remember as a Governor, when this idea was floated by Tommy Thompson, the Governors—Republican and Democrats—said, please let us do that. We can care for our own poor in so much better and more effective a way than having the Federal Government tell us how to care for our poor.
171.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

172.speaker: Gov. Romney
172.text: So let States—one of the magnificent things about this country is the whole idea that States are the laboratories of democracy. Don't have the Federal Government tell everybody what kind of training programs they have to have and what kind of Medicaid they have to have. Let States do this. And by the way, if a State gets in trouble, well, we could step in and see if we could find a way to help them.
172.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

173.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
173.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

174.speaker: Gov. Romney.
174.text: But the right approach is one which relies on the brilliance of our people and States, not the Federal Government.
174.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

175.speaker: Social Security/Medicare
175.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

176.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
176.text: Two seconds and we're going on, still on the economy, but another part of it. All right, this is segment three, the economy. Entitlements, first answer goes to you, two minutes, Mr. President. Do you see a major difference between the two of you on Social Security?
176.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

177.speaker: The President.
177.text: I suspect that on Social Security we've got a somewhat similar position. Social Security is structurally sound. It's going to have to be tweaked the way it was by Ronald Reagan and Speaker—Democratic Speaker Tip O'Neill. But it is—the basic structure is sound.
177.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

178.speaker: The President.
178.text: But I want to talk about the values behind Social Security and Medicare and then talk about Medicare because that's the big driver of our deficits right now.
178.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

179.speaker: The President.
179.text: My grandmother, some of you know, helped to raise me, my grandparents did. My grandfather died a while back. My grandmother died 3 days before I was elected President. And she was fiercely independent. She worked her way up. Only had a high school education, started as a secretary, ended up being the vice president of a local bank. And she ended up living alone by choice. And the reason she could be independent was because of Social Security and Medicare.
179.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

180.speaker: The President.
180.text: She had worked all her life, put in this money, and understood that there was a basic guarantee, a floor under which she could not go. And that's the perspective I bring when I think about what's called entitlements. The name itself implies some sense of dependency on the part of these folks. These are folks who've worked hard, like my grandmother, and there are millions of people out there who are counting on this.
180.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

181.speaker: The President.
181.text: So my approach is to say, how do we strengthen the system over the long term. And in Medicare, what we did was we said we are going to have to bring down the costs if we're going to deal with our long-term deficits, but to do that, let's look where some of the money is going: $716 billion we were able to save from the Medicare program by no longer overpaying insurance companies, by making sure that we weren't overpaying providers. And using that money, we were actually able to lower prescription drug costs for seniors by an average of $600, and we were also able to make a significant dent in providing them the kind of preventive care that will ultimately save money through the—throughout the system.
181.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

182.speaker: The President.
182.text: So the way for us to deal with Medicare in particular is to lower health care costs. When it comes to Social Security, as I said, you don't need a major structural change in order to make sure that Social Security is there for the future.
182.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

183.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
183.text: We'll follow up on this. First, Governor Romney, you have 2 minutes on Social Security and entitlements.
183.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

184.speaker: Gov. Romney.
184.text: Well, Jim, our seniors depend on these programs, and I know any time we talk about entitlements people become concerned that something is going to happen that's going to change their life for the worse. And the answer is, neither the President, nor I are proposing any changes for any current retirees or near-retirees, either to Social Security or Medicare. So if you're 60 or around 60 or older, you don't need to listen any further.
184.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

185.speaker: Gov. Romney.
185.text: But for younger people, we need to talk about what changes are going to be occurring—oh, I just thought about one, and that is, in fact, I was wrong when I said the President isn't proposing any changes for current retirees. In fact, he is on Medicare. On Social Security, he's not. But on Medicare, for current retirees, he's cutting $716 billion from the program. Now, he says by not overpaying hospitals and providers. Actually, just going to them and saying we're going to reduce the rates you get paid across the board, everybody is going to get a lower rate, that's not just going after places where there's abuse. That's saying, we're cutting the rates. Some 15 percent of hospitals and nursing homes say they won't take any more Medicare patients under that scenario. We also have 50 percent of doctors who say they won't take more Medicare patients.
185.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

186.speaker: Gov. Romney.
186.text: This—we have 4 million people on Medicare Advantage that will lose Medicare Advantage because of those $716 billion in cuts. I can't understand how you can cut Medicare $716 billion for current recipients of Medicare. Now, you'd point out, well, we're putting some back, we're going to give a better prescription program. That's one of—that's $1 for every 15 you've cut. They're smart enough to know that's not a good trade.
186.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

187.speaker: Gov. Romney.
187.text: I want to take that $716 billion you've cut and put it back into Medicare. By the way, we can include a prescription program if we need to improve it. But the idea of cutting $716 billion from Medicare to be able to balance the additional cost of Obamacare is, in my opinion, a mistake.
187.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

188.speaker: Gov. Romney.
188.text: And with regards to young people coming along, I've got proposals to make sure Medicare and Social Security are there for them without any question.
188.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

189.speaker: Health Care for Senior Citizens/Medicare
189.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

190.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
190.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

191.speaker: The President.
191.text: First of all, I think it's important for Governor Romney to present this plan that he says will only affect folks in the future. And the essence of the plan is that you would turn Medicare into a voucher program. It's called premium support, but it's understood to be a voucher program. His running mate——
191.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

192.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
192.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

193.speaker: The President.
193.text: I don't. And let me explain why.
193.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

194.speaker: Gov. Romney.
194.text: Again, that's for future people, right——
194.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

195.speaker: The President.
195.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

196.speaker: Gov. Romney.
196.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

197.speaker: The President.
197.text: So if you're 54 or 55, you might want to listen, because this will affect you.
197.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

198.speaker: The President.
198.text: The idea, which was originally presented by Congressman Ryan, your running mate, is that we would give a voucher to seniors and they could go out in the private marketplace and buy their own health insurance. The problem is that because the voucher wouldn't necessarily keep up with health care inflation, it was estimated that this would cost the average senior about $6,000 a year.
198.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

199.speaker: The President.
199.text: Now, in fairness, what Governor Romney has now said is, he'll maintain traditional Medicare alongside it. But there's still a problem, because what happens is those insurance companies are pretty clever at figuring out who are the younger and healthier seniors. They recruit them, leaving the older, sicker seniors in Medicare, and every health care economist who looks at it says, over time, what will happen is the traditional Medicare system will collapse. And then what you've got is folks like my grandmother at the mercy of the private insurance system precisely at the time when they are most in need of decent health care.
199.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

200.speaker: The President.
200.text: So I don't think vouchers are the right way to go. And this is not my—only my opinion. AARP thinks that the savings that we obtained from Medicare bolstered the system, lengthened the Medicare trust fund by 8 years. Benefits were not affected at all.
200.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

201.speaker: laughter
201.text: And ironically, if you repeal Obamacare—and I have become fond of this term, Obamacare—[
201.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

202.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
202.text: We'll talk about—specifically about health care in a moment. But what—do you support the voucher system, Governor?
202.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

203.speaker: Gov. Romney.
203.text: What I support is no change for current retirees and near-retirees to Medicare. And the President supports taking $716 billion out of that program.
203.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

204.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
204.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

205.speaker: Gov. Romney.
205.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

206.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
206.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

207.speaker: Gov. Romney.
207.text: Number two is, for people coming along that are young, what I'd do to make sure that we can keep Medicare in place for them is to allow them either to choose the current Medicare program or a private plan, their choice. They get to—and they'll have at least two plans that will be entirely at no cost to them. So they don't have to pay additional money, no additional $6,000; that's not going to happen. They'll have at least two plans.
207.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

208.speaker: Gov. Romney.
208.text: And by the way, if the Government can be as efficient as the private sector and offer premiums that are as low as the private sector, people will be happy to get traditional Medicare. Or they'll be able to get a private plan. I know my own view is, I'd rather have a private plan. I'd just as soon not have the Government telling me what kind of health care I get. I'd rather be able to have an insurance company. If I don't like them, I can get rid of them and find a different insurance company. But people will make their own choice.
208.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

209.speaker: Gov. Romney.
209.text: The other thing we have to do to save Medicare, we have to have the benefits high for those that are low income. But for higher-income people, we're going to have to lower some of the benefits. We have to make sure this program is there for the long term.
209.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

210.speaker: Gov. Romney.
210.text: That's the plan that I put forward. And by the way, the idea came not even from Paul Ryan or Senator Wyden, who is a coauthor of the bill with Paul Ryan in the Senate, but also it came from Bill Clinton's Chief of Staff. This is an idea that's been around a long time, which is saying, hey, let's see if we can't get competition into the Medicare world so that people can get the choice of different plans at lower cost, better quality. I believe in competition.
210.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

211.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
211.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

212.speaker: The President.
212.text: Jim, if I can just respond very quickly. First of all, every study has shown that Medicare has lower administrative costs than private insurance does, which is why seniors are generally pretty happy with it. And private insurers have to make a profit. Nothing wrong with that, that's what they do. And so you've got higher administrative costs, plus profit on top of that, and if you are going to save any money through what Governor Romney is proposing, what has to happen is, is that the money has to come from somewhere.
212.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

213.speaker: The President.
213.text: And when you move to a voucher system, you are putting seniors at the mercy of those insurance companies. And over time, if traditional Medicare has decayed or fallen apart, then they're stuck. And this is the reason why AARP has said that your plan would weaken Medicare substantially, and that's why they were supportive of the approach that we took.
213.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

214.speaker: The President.
214.text: One last point I want to make: We do have to lower the cost of health care, not just in Medicare, but——
214.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

215.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
215.text: We'll talk about that in a minute.
215.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

216.speaker: The President.
216.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

217.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
217.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

218.speaker: The President.
218.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

219.speaker: Gov. Romney.
219.text: That's a big topic. Can we stay on Medicare?
219.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

220.speaker: The President.
220.text: Oh, is that a separate topic?
220.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

221.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
221.text: Yes, we're going to—yes, I want to get to it.
221.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

222.speaker: The President.
222.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

223.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
223.text: But all I want to do is very quickly——
223.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

224.speaker: Gov. Romney.
224.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

225.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
225.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

226.speaker: Gov. Romney.
226.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

227.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
227.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

228.speaker: Gov. Romney.
228.text: The President said that the Government can provide the service at lower cost and without a profit.
228.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

229.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
229.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

230.speaker: Gov. Romney.
230.text: If that's the case, then it will always be the best product that people can purchase. But my experience——
230.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

231.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
231.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

232.speaker: Gov. Romney.
232.text: ——my experience is the private sector typically is able to provide a better product at a lower cost.
232.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

233.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
233.text: Can we—can the two of you agree that the voters have a choice, a clear choice between the two of you on Medicare?
233.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

234.speaker: Gov. Romney.
234.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

235.speaker: The President.
235.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

236.speaker: Gov. Romney.
236.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

237.speaker: The President.
237.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

238.speaker: Federal Regulations/Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
238.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

239.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
239.text: All right. So to finish quickly, briefly on the economy, what is your view about the level of Federal regulation of the economy right now? Is there too much? And in your case, Mr. President, is there—should there be more? Beginning with you—this is not a new 2-minute segment. Just start, and we'll go for a few minutes, and then we're going to go to health care, okay?
239.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

240.speaker: Gov. Romney.
240.text: Regulation is essential. You can't have a free market work if you don't have regulation. As a businessperson, I had to have—I needed to know the regulations. I needed them there. You couldn't have people opening up banks in their garage and making loans. I mean, you have to have regulations so that you can have an economy work. Every free economy has good regulation. At the same time, regulation can become excessive.
240.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

241.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
241.text: Is it successing now, do you think?
241.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

242.speaker: Gov. Romney.
242.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

243.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
243.text: Like where? Let me know. Give me——
243.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

244.speaker: Gov. Romney.
244.text: ——other places, no. It can become out of date. And what's happened with some of the legislation that's been passed during the President's term, you've seen regulation become excessive, and it's hurt the economy.
244.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

245.speaker: Gov. Romney.
245.text: Let me give you an example. Dodd-Frank was passed, and it includes within it a number of provisions that I think has some unintended consequences that are harmful to the economy. One is it designates a number of banks as "too big to fail," and they're effectively guaranteed by the Federal Government. This is the biggest kiss that's been given to New York banks I've ever seen.
245.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

246.speaker: The President.
246.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

247.speaker: Gov. Romney.
247.text: This is an enormous boon for them. There have been 122 community and small banks have closed since Dodd-Frank. So there's one example.
247.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

248.speaker: Gov. Romney.
248.text: Here's another. In Dodd-Frank, it says if——
248.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

249.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
249.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

250.speaker: Gov. Romney.
250.text: Well, I would repeal the—and replace it. We're not going to get rid of all regulation. You have to have regulation——
250.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

251.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
251.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

252.speaker: Gov. Romney.
252.text: ——and there are some parts of DoddFrank that make all the sense in the world. You need transparency. You need to have leverage limits for institutional——
252.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

253.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
253.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

254.speaker: Gov. Romney.
254.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

255.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
255.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

256.speaker: Gov. Romney.
256.text: Let me mention the other one. Let's talk the other big one—the big one.
256.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

257.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
257.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

258.speaker: Gov. Romney.
258.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

259.speaker: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act/Home Loan Industry
259.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

260.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
260.text: Let's let him respond to this specific on Dodd-Frank and what the Governor just said.
260.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

261.speaker: The President.
261.text: Well, I think this is a great example. The reason we have been in such a enormous economic crisis was prompted by reckless behavior across the board. Now, it wasn't just on Wall Street. You had loan officers were—that were giving loans and mortgages that really shouldn't have been given because the folks didn't qualify. You had people who were borrowing money to buy a house that they couldn't afford. You had credit agencies that were stamping these as A1, great investments when they weren't. But you also had banks making money hand over fist, churning out products that the bankers themselves didn't even understand, in order to make big profits, but knowing that it made the entire system vulnerable.
261.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

262.speaker: The President.
262.text: So what did we do? We stepped in and had the toughest reforms on Wall Street since the 1930s. We said you've got—banks, you've got to raise your capital requirements. You can't engage in some of this risky behavior that is putting Main Street at risk. We're going to make sure that you've got to have a living will so we can know how you're going to wind things down if you make a bad bet so we don't have other taxpayer bailouts.
262.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

263.speaker: The President.
263.text: In the meantime, by the way, we also made sure that all the help that we provided those banks was paid back—every single dime—with interest.
263.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

264.speaker: The President.
264.text: Now, Governor Romney has said he wants to repeal Dodd-Frank, and I appreciate—and it appears we've got some agreement that a marketplace, to work, has to have some regulation. But in the past, Governor Romney has said he just wants to repeal Dodd-Frank. Roll it back. And so the question is, does anybody out there think that the big problem we had is that there was too much oversight and regulation of Wall Street? Because if you do, then Governor Romney is your candidate. But that's not——
264.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

265.speaker: Gov. Romney.
265.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

266.speaker: The President.
266.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

267.speaker: Gov. Romney.
267.text: ——but that's just not the facts. Look, we have to have regulation on Wall Street. That's why I'd have regulation. But I wouldn't designate five banks as "too big to fail" and give them a blank check. That's one of the unintended consequences of Dodd-Frank. It wasn't thought through properly. We need to get rid of that provision because it's killing regional and small banks. They're getting hurt.
267.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

268.speaker: Gov. Romney.
268.text: Let me mention another regulation in Dodd-Frank. You say we were giving mortgages to people who weren't qualified. That's exactly right. It's one of the reasons for the great financial calamity we had. And so Dodd-Frank correctly says we need to have qualified mortgages, and if you give a mortgage that's not qualified, there are big penalties—except they didn't ever go on to define what a qualified mortgage was.
268.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

269.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
269.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

270.speaker: Gov. Romney.
270.text: It's been 2 years. We don't know what a qualified mortgage is yet.
270.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

271.speaker: Gov. Romney.
271.text: So banks are reluctant to make loans, mortgages. Try and get a mortgage these days. It's hurt the housing market, because Dodd-Frank. didn't anticipate putting in place the kinds of regulations you have to have. It's not that Dodd-Frank always was wrong with too much regulation. Sometimes they didn't come out with a clear regulation.
271.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

272.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
272.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

273.speaker: Gov. Romney
273.text: . I will make sure we don't hurt the functioning of our marketplace and our businesses, because I want to bring back housing and get good jobs.
273.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

274.speaker: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
274.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Denver, Colorado

275.speaker: Mr. Lehrer.
275.text: All right. I think we have another clear difference between the two of you. Now let's move to health care, where I know there is a clear difference—[
